utterances: On the other hand, what often happened in these cases is that the folks in the community had some link to these people.
They knew who some of the perpetrators were, so I would suggest that there's probably some evidence still locally about kinds of hints that lead to enough evidence to move on this case.
And the larger question really becomes, you know, what is the perception of Mississippi and really as a country are still wrangling around these race issues?
This was an opportunity, I think for the federal government to move forward and try to put to rest some of these notorious cases that happened during the civil right movement.
And Callie, you beat me to my next question, and Nat, pick up on this if you would.

And that is when you reopen a case like this to the fanfare that the FBI allowed for this without warning up front that the statute was there and it may be problematic, you tend to dash the hopes of many who looked to the justice department and others to right wrongs.
Sure you do, Ed.

And we still have - you know, if you're a baby boomer, a black baby boomer, a white baby boomer for that matter, the case of Emmett Till still resonates because of the visual images that we have from the Jet magazine photo of Emmett Till's body.

I think, you know, when we compare the decision by the FBI, whom today has decided not to pursue this case, compare that with the decision by next door neighbor Alabama to go back and pardon the number of folks who had been charges with violating the segregational laws, you see a part of our country who's trying to deal with a very painful part of our history.
We make progress and we fall back.
I think the opportunity that the state has, Mississippi, maybe the district attorney will follow-up, I'm certainly hopeful that the folks in Mississippi will not let this thing just fester.
This is not something that's just going to go away.

We'll be talking about this case 10 years from now, 20 years from now, 30 years from now, and this is an opportunity, while the people are still alive who do know what happened, to come forward and help us to heal a very...
All right, and we should note as everyone has alluded there, that the state in fact can still bring charges, that the statute of limitation does not apply in the same way there.
And many people are hoping that the state will pick up from here and continue.
Joe, did you have - I thought you were trying to get in on it.

Well, one of the things that I think it particularly galling about this particular case is that this is a case that, in a sense, drove the civil rights movement from the very beginning almost, and so it became kind of an icon of the civil rights movement and what can happen to black people in the South for little or no offense at all.
And so I think there's a lot of emotion with this case, as there certainly - and that's totally understandable.
I have a lot of emotion about it, and I think every black person does.
And so for this outcome, it feels so unsatisfactory, you know, even if on a strictly legal basis it was - it makes sense.
And I don't know all the ins and outs of FBI's case or lack of a case, but it leaves us wanting because of the power of this case over decades.
All right.
Let me bring this up.

In terms of trying to right a wrong, if you will, even though Nat jumped the gun on me there for a second, but Alabama lawmakers are considering pardoning hundreds, even thousands or people who were arrested decades ago for violating Alabama segregation law.
This would, in fact, include Rosa Parks, whose conviction is still on the record.
Callie, you know, many people say that it's a nicety, but it doesn't do anything.
Others feel that it helps close a wound.
What do you think?
And we should note that this would be called the Rosa Parks Act.
I think there is power in acknowledgment, and that this makes a statement.
And a lot of people say to me, well, you know, some of these superficial apologies, what does it mean in the end because they're not really sincere.
I don't really care if they're sincere.
I think there is power in the acknowledgement.
This happened.
This was not correct.
Here are the people who were involved, and we're making an official statement, and I think that says something.
But if it's not sincere what does it correct other than the record which most people won't go to anyway?
Well, first of all, I'm not...
I think it corrects...
Go ahead.
I'm sorry.
I was just going to say it corrects a lot.
First of all, if you were arrested during that period, as many people were, you have an arrest record.
And just in terms of full disclosure, my former father-in-law is Fred Shuttlesworth, who was arrested many times, because he led the Birmingham movement, and so people have an arrest record.
And so there's some practical importance to pardoning everyone.
Well, you know, I think I'm with Callie on this.
Sometimes it's hard to get to people's intentions when, you know, one of their legislators said he couldn't imagine anyone opposing it.
I doubt if anybody would oppose the matter, but there would be people who privately would oppose it.

What I think is important, aside from the pardons, and this is what I wish sometimes that we could do in terms of race relations in this country when it comes to our history, is sometimes that we could just acknowledge that we're sorry for what happened.
If we can just find a way for people to just say look, we shouldn't have been this way.
This is the way our country was.

There were a lot of people who were silent when things that were being done - when black people were being terrorized by its own government, by the local officials and full knowledge of local citizens who should have done something about it, and they didn't do anything about it.
A part of the healing is just to say, we shouldn't have done that, and this is a small step, but I don't see what's wrong with just saying we're sorry.
A pardon is a formal kind of declaration of it, but the problem with it is that it says that you did something wrong.
Hell, they didn't do anything wrong.
What was wrong was the way people were being treated, and this is a part of the process, but it doesn't do it all.
Well, for those of you...
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""IF I KNEW"")
I would just like to remind everybody that the first step in any twelve step program is acknowledgement, so we can't even get to talking about any issue beyond that.
You must acknowledge first.

Well, we should then note for those who are as fervent about this as the panel seems to be, this is being considered and if you'd like to see it moved through, you should contact Alabama lawmakers and say that you believe this is a good idea.
Okay, let's take a look at the White House.
The president restated his terrorist strategy in a national security strategy that was released this week.
His doctrine says preemptive war against terrorism in hostile states with chemical, biological, and nuclear weapons will continue from the United States.
One of the things, Joe Davidson, that people also heard this week were the whispers about how the United States is taking a look at Iran.
This coupled with that tells us what?
Well, I think based on history, recent history over the last four or five years, I think it's the kind of thing that might make Iran nervous because of what happened with its neighbor Iraq.

However, I think it should also be noted that as a, that even though the United States invaded Iraq and even though Iran has long been, on it's watch list as evildoers, Iran is proceeding with its nuclear program.
So it's not at all clear that this type of strategy works to dismay Iran or other countries from going along their chosen path when that chosen path conflicts with U.S.
objectives.

Callie, I'm curious when you here this, when you see the president not stepping away at all, standing in the gale wind, when you see the latest polls that show him at 38 and 36 percent approval rating and that 60 percent of the people are suggesting that the war's going poorly.
When you see Howard Baker and others suggesting that a shake up is needed in the White House, what do you think about this administration that clearly has not moved at all?
It's stubborn and I mean the man himself has said that.
Listen I take my stand, I make no bones about it and when I've decided something is going to go this way I'm sticking, staying the course.
I believe that's his terminology.
So that's what I observe.

I would hope, and we've seen some evidence, the Dubai thing is one thing, the Harriet Meyers is another situation where there have been some forces on his side per se that have forced him to back away, change or adjust.
I don't know if that's going to be successful now because he's sticking in there with this war and...
...Irvin...
...his own party, or saying something different.
Nat Irvin, American some years ago clamored for this kind of politician, look right or wrong stick by your beliefs, we don't want to see this wishy-washy mess.
Well, I tell you, Ed, George Bush's stubbornness has been an asset and has also a liability.
I have not read the entire report this new National Security Strategy report, I read some of it.
And you know I tell you that a couple of things, one I think it's actually, it's a lot, there's a subtle shift in this report.
And I don't think even though a lot has been made about the preemptive strategies that one of The president's aids made a point of talking about and the media's picked up on.
Is actually less of a unilateralist approach and more of a multilateral approach than have been the case in 2002?

In other words I think what's happened is the administration's talking to him, but if you look and listen we still have the same principals, in terms of what have always been the hallmarks of foreign policy for America.
But the fact that we made a mistake with the preemptive strike into Iraq based on false information about WMDs.
This administration and this report is saying, they're acknowledging that and I think that in terms of the countries response.
Yeah.
Preemptive strike is a no go.
From now on it's Jerry McGuire: show me the weapons before you do anything.
Despite the whole thing about Iran our, you know, the axis of evil I'm not buying it.
I don't think we're going to do anything there.
All right let me get to this very quickly because it only gives us a minute for each of you.
But again, yet more data released this week--and certainly we've seen the nation pay attention to the bell curve of years ago.

This is analyzed by two economists, one from Harvard, one from the University of Chicago, which suggests that there are very small racial differences in mental functioning of children age eight to 12 months.
And that in fact, Asian children, Asian children score slightly below white and black kids.
This put next to what we have seen before, again, Callie Crossley says what if anything?
I don't know what it says, you know.
I just think it confuses people and, I mean I think we just have to go with the fact that there, anytime that you touch this subject it goes off into all kinds of tangents.
And I'd like to see some more conversation about this from some other folks.
This just doesn't make sense to me.
I guess maybe I'm not a scientist, I don't get this.
I really don't, and I just think it stirs up a pot that continues to be stirred that doesn't have much evidence in it.
Well I think the bottom line though is that the researchers came to the conclusion that there is very little, if any significant difference in the intelligence of black and white and Asian babies.
And when they did a series of tests as you alluded to, Ed.

In this case the Asians babies came out slightly somewhat behind, but we know that when it comes to those doing work at the college level for example or throughout school level that certainly is not the case.
So I think that this study basically shows that there is no significant difference if any difference at all.

Well it certainly going to continue in that matter of a debate between nature and nurture, because as Joe alluded to, after that 11 month period we start to see the gap widen and certainly by high school and college the gap is large in terms of standardized testing.
Yeah, and, you know, I'm in a position where I represent the university and I am stating what I believe to be something the university ought to acknowledge and ought to acknowledge with regret.
It is a part of our history that we wish were different, but it wasn't.

I used to get really bothered by all this crap by social scientists, the white social scientists, you know, who used to perpetuate this whole idea that somehow blacks were less intelligent than anybody else.
And you know when, but I stopped worry about it a couple of things happened.
First of all my wife and I are parents of three children.
When they were born each one of them was more brilliant that came before, and they are now.
And I just, you know, it, for, that's the first thing.
Second thing is, the more we read about the history of social science and the more we read about science in general, we know we know less about what we're talking about.
And I respect Steven Levitt and Ron (unintelligible); both of them are brilliant econometrics.
Economists who have these great statistical models and I appreciate their interest in this area.
But it doesn't mean anything to me because it's not going to mean anything in the future.

What is important as we learn more about us as a species is that the key thing is going to be working on the environment we live in, trying to provide better opportunities for people and I just don't pay any attention to anything that comes out about measuring race and intelligence.
Because I know people don't know what they're talking about.
Right.
Amen, amen, amen.
Callie, Joe and Nat thank you very much.
And the one thing we're sure of is that we'll hear from Nat's two oldest children or at least he will because he clearly said the youngest was the most brilliant in that house.
But, they all brilliant.
